text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

L. RAFAEL REIF: In
creating OCW, MIT

launched a quiet, but profound
educational revolution.

It unleashed the global
open sharing movement

and helped pave the way for
the worldwide phenomenon
of open digital learning.

SANJAY SARMA: What
are two or three words

to describe
OpenCourseWare's impact?
I would say knowledge at scale.
LEO ALCOCK: Eye opening.
MUSSIE DEMISSE: Enlightening.

SARAH HANSEN: Choose
your own adventure.
ZACH ERDMAN: A whole new world.
JAMES GLAPA-GROSSKLAG: Wow.

20 years of MIT's
OpenCourseWare.

That's just amazing
to think about.

KRISHNA RAJAGOPAL: We've had
more than 200 million people

come to OCW and learn from the
materials that MIT is sharing.

MUSSIE DEMISSE: My initial
introduction to OpenCourseWare

was actually at Bunker
Hill Community College.

My linear algebra
professor would give us
these weekly quizzes.
We told her it was hard.

And she said actually,
this is an MIT quiz.

And I was kind of blown away
that I did some part of it.

And when I inquired how
she got the quiz, she said,

oh, there's this thing
called MIT OpenCourseWare.

It imparted me with
this confidence of,
oh, I can do this.
I can survive in an MIT course.

And that drove me to say
maybe I can thrive at MIT.

ABHAY PAREKH: OCW
was the pioneer.

It opened everybody's
eyes to the possibility

of connecting to
learners who are

in different countries
and different situations,
different ages.

MAY THET KHINE
NYEIN: We are making

the MIT OCW available in
universities and community

libraries, which do not
have internet connection.

ABOO FATALLY: It has
encouraged me to learn,

to find out about things,
to understand, and to apply.

CURT NEWTON: There
is so much that

can be achieved by
just giving people

complete wide open
access to this knowledge

that they can use
whenever, wherever, as much

as they need, as
little as they need.

AMAH EDOH: It
takes this very kind

of privileged elite
education that we

make accessible to our
students and opens it up
to a broader public.

JAMES GLAPA-GROSSKLAG:
The very existence

of MIT's OpenCourseWare
is inspiring.

It's a shining example
for institutions of higher
education around the world.

AMAH EDOH: I think
there's also great value

in showing the range of
disciplines that are taught

at MIT and showing the
fact that the humanities

and social sciences are
as much a strength of what

MIT has to offer as
the STEM disciplines.

This course that I created
is now part of the record

and is now something that
someone else can build on.

EVELYN LAURITO: Everything is
there-- even the syllabus, even

the instructions of the
teachers, thesis assignments.

ABOO FATALLY: OCW is
perhaps one of the best

thing that has happened
to education worldwide.

EVELYN LAURITO: It's
like being so unselfish.

You're giving everything
of what you have

and sharing it with
the other people,

especially in
developing countries,
like the Philippines.

LEO ALCOCK: OpenCourseWare
quite literally changed my life.

It gave me the education
I needed when there wasn't
another place to find it.

MUSSIE DEMISSE:
You're giving people

the tools that will allow them
to achieve their potential.

SARAH HANSEN: We have real
problems in the world that
need to be solved.

And we need problem solvers
from every area of the planet
to work on these.

CURT NEWTON: We've created
this powerful foundation
of free access to knowledge.

And together, we'll
keep growing it.

We're creating better ways
for learners and teachers

to find and to use
that OCW content.

And we'll keep sharing
that vibrant reflection

of the teaching and
creativity from MIT.

KRISHNA RAJAGOPAL: As
we think about equity,
we think about collaborators.

So that we can bring
more people starting

from different starting points
coming in at different ways

to the point that they
can learn from OCW.

CURT NEWTON: Together,
we're forging

new paths, where everyone's
contributing to the world's
growing knowledge.

And we're all using and sharing
that knowledge every day

to solve the world's
great challenges.

MUSSIE DEMISSE: I want
OCW to attract people.

So it's not just a neutral
if you want it, come get it.

I want OCW to be calling on
people to educate themselves,

to empower themselves,
to build and to have

the necessary tools to do
what they think is important.

SANJAY SARMA: And I'm hoping
that over time, this snowball

from 20 years ago
becomes an avalanche

of intellectual exchange
amongst humanity.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
